bibl.title: Letter from R.B. Maury to Howard A. Kelly, November 13, 1904

div1.p: Maury forwards Kelly a book on the yellow fever epidemic of 1878, as well as journal references. Maury contacts Lena Warner, a yellow fever survivor, for her recollections.

div1.head: Letter from R.B. Maury to Howard A. Kelly, November 13, 1904
div1.opener:
DRS. MAURY & ANDERSON.
EQUITABLE BLDG.
MEMPHIS, TENN.
Nov 13, 04
Dr Howard A Kelly
Baltimore
My Dear Dr.
div1.p:
It has taken me several
days to find anything which may help
you in the work of writing anything about
Yellow Fever.

I will send you by mail tomorrow
Keating's History of the Y. F. Epidemic
of 1878, a book out of print, but
this was found in an Old-books' store,
It will contain possibly all you will
want to read- If more is wanted
you can find in the Public Health Assoc-
iation reports Vol v. Vol vi 1879- Y. F. Epidemic
in Memphis & Memphis Sanitation &
Quarantine by Dr Thornton-

✓ Mrs Leena Warner, a young woman
whom I trained as a nurse, and who
afterwards served as a hospital nurse in
AC
Va
Cuba had the fever in Grenada in 1878.
(Five members of her family died of it then,
three only survived) and has promised me
to write some of her recollections of it.
There are no letters pertaining to it so
far as I know; or pamphlets; but Keatings
book will I trust be of value to you.
Many of our people could tell you
their experiences. In one family who
lived opposite my residence on Beale
St. there were 8 cases and 5 deaths,
Hoping these references will answer
your purposes, I remain
